newsitem.title: UK: UK gilts close up but still gutted by rout.
newsitem.headline: UK gilts close up but still gutted by rout.

text.p: Gilt futures made a spirited recovery on Friday after falling more than a full point in a sell-off on Thursday, sparked by a poorly covered auction. The June gilt future clawed its way up 19/32 to close at 112-15 as the UK market closed for a three-day weekend. But the contract failed to reclaim the key 112-28 level which traders said prompted Thursday's sell-off.
The lower price levels had attracted buyers back into the market.
"I would say that today's rally is more technical than anything else," one trader said.
"We had widened out to 150 against Germany overnight, that was one factor. Secondly, the yields at the long end of the market looked much better value."
By the close of trade on Friday the gilt/Bund spread had narrowed in to 145 basis points.
Traders said there was a slight flattening of the UK yield curve over the five to 10 year range but from there out to the ultra long 21 year stocks it was unchanged.
Traders were surprised that the recovery had come without the help of U.S. Treasuries, which only inched narrowly higher in moderate trade.
But they said gilts remained vulnerable to external pressures and would be watching a batch of U.S. data out next week for clues as to whether the Fed might raise interest rates.
